p: The results of this study demonstrate the potential of thyme oil, clove oil, and tea tree oil for use as antifungal agents against tested fungi strains ( Fusarium graminearum G87, Penicillium corylophilum CBMF1, and Aspergillus brasiliensis ATCC 16404) and three potential pathogenic food bacteria: Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, and Listeria monocytogenes. The overall results of the MIC values show that thyme oil is the most effective with a very low concentration used against both on the three fungi and bacteria, followed by clove and tea tree oils, while the rosemary oil is less active or inactive.
